extendedIngredients.name: red chile
extendedIngredients.original: 1/2 fresh red chile, according to size and taste, minced
extendedIngredients.originalName: fresh red chile, according to size and taste, minced

title: Shrimp with Garlic and Chili Pepper
summary: Shrimp with Garlic and Chili Pepper might be a good recipe to expand your main course recipe box. One serving contains 592 calories, 47g of protein, and 31g of fat. This recipe serves 1 and costs $6.98 per serving. 13 people have made this recipe and would make it again. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes roughly 7 minutes. A mixture of chile, salt, parsley leaves, and a handful of other ingredients are all it takes to make this recipe so flavorful. To use up the olive oil you could follow this main course with the Sauteed Banana, Granolan and Yogurt Parfait as a dessert. The Super Bowl will be even more special with this recipe. It is brought to you by Foodnetwork. A couple people really liked this American dish. It is a good option if you're following a caveman, gluten free, dairy free, and primal diet. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 84%. This score is excellent. Try Shrimp with Garlic and Chili Pepper, Steamed Luffa with Garlic and Chili Pepper Oil, and Garlic Pepper Shrimp for similar recipes.

winePairing.pairingText: Pinot Grigio, Riesling, and Sauvignon Blanc are my top picks for Shrimp. These crisp white wines work well with shrimp prepared in a variety of ways, whether grilled, fried, or in garlic sauce. One wine you could try is Thrive Pinot Grigio. It has 4.5 out of 5 stars and a bottle costs about 15 dollars.

instructions: Pour the olive oil into a wide, heavy-bottomed frying pan. Then add the chile and garlic and, over moderate to low heat, to infuse rather than to color, fry for 2 minutes, stirring all the time. Then turn the heat to high, add the shrimp, and stir-fry them for another 2 minutes or until they turn pink and are just, delicately, cooked; you want the flesh to stay tender. Pour in the white wine and let it bubble up. You don't want a liquid puddle around the shrimp, just enough wine to let the juices ooze into a winy sauce. Another minute or so should do it. Season with the salt, if necessary, and then turn into your bowl and sprinkle with parsley. Eat with some good hunks of baguette. I eat these carapace, head, and all: one of the reasons I designate them for solitary dinner.                          If you want, you can add a tablespoonful or so of brandy before throwing in the wine.

steps.step: Pour the olive oil into a wide, heavy-bottomed frying pan. Then add the chile and garlic and, over moderate to low heat, to infuse rather than to color, fry for 2 minutes, stirring all the time. Then turn the heat to high, add the shrimp, and stir-fry them for another 2 minutes or until they turn pink and are just, delicately, cooked; you want the flesh to stay tender.

Pour in the white wine and let it bubble up. You don't want a liquid puddle around the shrimp, just enough wine to let the juices ooze into a winy sauce. Another minute or so should do it. Season with the salt, if necessary, and then turn into your bowl and sprinkle with parsley. Eat with some good hunks of baguette. I eat these carapace, head, and all: one of the reasons I designate them for solitary dinner.
If you want, you can add a tablespoonful or so of brandy before throwing in the wine.
